claim: Jews do not all speak one language.

supporting.text: Hebrew is the liturgical language of Judaism, but not all Jews speak it fluently as a native language.

attacks.text: Hebrew is the liturgical language of Judaism, but not all Jews speak it fluently as a native language.
Many Jews in Israel speak Hebrew as their primary language, which contradicts the claim that Jews do not all speak one language.
While Hebrew is spoken in Israel, many Jews in the diaspora do not speak it fluently, supporting the original claim.
Yiddish is another language spoken by many Ashkenazi Jews, further supporting the claim that Jews do not all speak one language.
Yiddish is declining in usage, and many younger Jews do not speak it, which weakens the argument that it is a widely spoken language among Jews.

supporting.text: Yiddish, a language historically spoken by Ashkenazi Jews, is distinct from Hebrew and not universally known among all Jewish communities.

attacks.text: Yiddish, a language historically spoken by Ashkenazi Jews, is distinct from Hebrew and not universally known among all Jewish communities.
Hebrew is the liturgical language of Judaism and is widely studied or understood by religious Jews globally, suggesting some linguistic commonality.
Modern Hebrew is primarily spoken in Israel, while many diaspora Jewish communities primarily use local languages (e.g., English, Russian, French).
Ladino (Judeo-Spanish) is another Jewish language spoken by Sephardic Jews, further demonstrating linguistic diversity.
Many secular or assimilated Jews may not speak any Jewish language at all, relying solely on their country's dominant language.

supporting.text: Ladino, spoken by Sephardic Jews, is another Jewish language separate from Hebrew and Yiddish, further demonstrating linguistic diversity.

attacks.text: Ladino, spoken by Sephardic Jews, is another Jewish language separate from Hebrew and Yiddish, further demonstrating linguistic diversity.
Hebrew is the liturgical language of Judaism, and many Jews worldwide learn it, suggesting a unifying linguistic element.
Liturgical use of Hebrew does not equate to daily spoken language, as most Jews do not use Hebrew conversationally outside Israel.
Many Jewish communities have shifted to dominant local languages (e.g., English, Russian), reducing active use of distinct Jewish languages.
Language shift does not erase historical linguistic diversity, as Ladino/Yiddish remain culturally significant even if less spoken.

supporting.text: Jewish diaspora communities often adopt the dominant languages of their host countries, such as English, Russian, or Spanish, rather than a single shared Jewish language.

attacks.text: Jewish diaspora communities often adopt the dominant languages of their host countries, such as English, Russian, or Spanish, rather than a single shared Jewish language.
Hebrew is a shared liturgical and cultural language among Jews worldwide, serving as a unifying linguistic element despite diaspora diversity.
Modern Hebrew is primarily spoken in Israel and not uniformly adopted by global Jewish communities, limiting its role as a universal Jewish language.
Yiddish and Ladino historically functioned as lingua francas for Ashkenazi and Sephardic Jews, respectively, suggesting regional linguistic unity subgroups.
Both Yiddish and Ladino have experienced severe decline in the 20th century, with fewer than 1 million combined speakers today.
Religious texts like the Torah are studied in their original Hebrew across all Jewish communities, creating functional linguistic commonality.
Liturgical Hebrew comprehension varies widely, with many Jews relying on translations for daily practice and study.

supporting.text: Modern Israel has Hebrew as its official language, but many Jewish immigrants and their descendants speak other languages, reflecting global linguistic diversity.

attacks.text: Modern Israel has Hebrew as its official language, but many Jewish immigrants and their descendants speak other languages, reflecting global linguistic diversity.
Hebrew is the liturgical language of Judaism, and many Jews worldwide learn it for religious purposes, creating a common linguistic thread.
Liturgical use of Hebrew does not equate to everyday spoken fluency, as many Jews primarily use local languages in daily life.
Historical Jewish diaspora communities like Yiddish-speaking Ashkenazim or Ladino-speaking Sephardim developed distinct Jewish languages.
Over 50% of Israeli Jews are native Hebrew speakers, suggesting significant linguistic unification among at least half the global Jewish population.
Native Hebrew speakers still represent a minority of worldwide Jews, as most diaspora communities maintain their local languages.

supporting.text: Historical Jewish communities, such as those in Ethiopia or India, developed their own distinct languages or dialects, unrelated to Hebrew or other Jewish languages.

attacks.text: Historical Jewish communities, such as those in Ethiopia or India, developed their own distinct languages or dialects, unrelated to Hebrew or other Jewish languages.
Hebrew is the liturgical language of Judaism, and many Jewish communities historically used Hebrew or Aramaic for religious purposes, creating a linguistic commonality.
Even if Hebrew was used liturgically, daily communication among Jewish communities often relied on local or regional languages, reinforcing linguistic diversity.
Modern Israel has adopted Hebrew as its official language, unifying many Jewish communities linguistically in the present day.
Despite Hebrew's revival in Israel, many diaspora Jewish communities continue to speak their historical languages (e.g., Yiddish, Ladino, Judeo-Arabic) or local languages, maintaining diversity.
